div.stage: At one door, Enter Cleopatra, Charmion, Iras, and Alexas, a Train of Aegyptians: at the other, Antony and Romans. The entrance on both sides is prepar'd by Musick; the Trumpets first sounding on Antony's part: then answer'd by Timbrels, &c. on Cleopatra's. Charmion and Iras hold a Laurel Wreath betwixt them. A Dance of Aegyptians. After the Ceremony, Cleopatra Crowns Antony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I Thought how those white arms would fold me in,
And strain me close, and melt me into love;
So pleas'd with that sweet Image, I sprung forwards,
And added all my strength to every blow.

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: Come to me, come my Soldier, to my Arms,
You've been too long away from my embraces;
But, when I have you fast, and all my own,
With broken murmurs, and with amorous sighs,
I'll say, you were unkind, and punish you,
And mark you red with many an eager kiss.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Brighter Venus!

sp.speaker: Cleo.
sp.l: O my greater Mars!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou joinst us well, my Love!
Suppose me come from the Phlegraean Plains,
Where gasping Gyants lay, cleft by my Sword:
And Mountain tops par'd off each other blow,
To bury those I slew: receive me, Goddess:
Let Caesar spread his subtle Nets, like Vulcan,
In thy embraces I would be beheld
By Heav'n and Earth at once:
And make their envy what they meant their sport
Let those who took us blush; I would love on
With awful State, regardless of their frowns,
As their superior God.
There's no satiety of Love, in thee;
Enjoy'd, thou still art new; perpetual Spring
Is in thy arms; the ripen'd fruit but falls,
And blossoms rise to fill its empty place;
And I grow rich by giving.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O, now the danger's past, your General 〈◊〉
He joyns not in your joys, nor minds your Triumphs,
But, with contracted brows, looks frowning on,
As envying your Success.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now, on my Soul, he loves me; truly loves me;
He never flatter'd me in any vice,
But awes me with his virtue: ev'n this minute
Methinks he has a right of chiding me.
Lead to the Temple: I'll avoid his presence;
It checks too strong upon me.
sp.stage: As Antony is going, Ventidius pulls him by the Robe.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Emperor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis the old argument; I pr'ythee spare me.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: But this one hearing, Emperor.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let go
My Robe; or, by my Father Hercules—.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: By Hercules his Father, that's yet greater,
I bring you somewhat you would wish to know.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou see'st we are observ'd; attend me here,
And I'll return.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I'm waining in his favour, yet I love him;
I love this Man, who runs to meet his ruin;
And, sure the Gods, like me, are fond of him:
His Virtues lye so mingled with his Crimes,
As would confound their choice to punish one,
And not reward the other.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We can conquer,
You see, without your aid.
We have dislodg'd their Troops,
They look on us at distance, and, like Curs
Scap'd from the Lions paws, they bay far off,
And lick their wounds, and saintly threaten War.
Five thousand Romans with their faces upward,
•… ye breathless on the Plain.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: 'Tis well: and he
Who lost 'em, could have spar'd Ten thousand more,
Yet if, by this advantage, you could gain
An easier Peace, while Caesar doubts the Chance
Of Arms!—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O think not on't, Ventidius;
The Boy pursues my ruin, he •… ll no peace:
His malice is considerate in advantage;
O, he's the coolest Murderer, so stanch,
He kills, and keeps his temper.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Have you no friend
In all his Army, who has power to move him,
Mecaenas, or Agrippa might do much.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They're both too deep in Caesar's interests,
We'll work it out by dint of Sword, or perish,

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: •… ain I would find some other.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thank thy love.
Some four or five such Victories as this,
Will save thy farther pains.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Expect no more; Caesar is on his Guard:
I know, Sir, you have conquer'd against odds;
But still you draw Supplies from one poor Town,
And of Aegyptians: He has all the World,
And, at his back, Nations come pouring in,
To fill the gaps you make. Pray think again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why dost thou drive me from my self, to search
For Foreign aids? to hunt my memory,
And range all o'er a wast and barren place
To find a Friend? The wretched have no Friends—
Yet I had one, the bravest Youth of Rome,
Whom Caesar loves beyond the Love of Women;
He could resolve his mind, as Fire does Wax,
From that hard rugged Image, melt him down,
And mould him in what softer form he pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Him would I see; that Man of all the world:
Just such a one we want.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He lov'd me too.
I was his Soul; he liv'd not but in me:
We were so clos'd within each others Breasts,
The Rivets were not found that join'd us first.
That does not reach us yet: we were so mixt,
As meeting Streams, both to our selves were lost;
We were one Mass; we could not give or take,
But from the same; for he was I, I he.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: He moves as I would wish him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: After this,
I need not tell his Name: 'twas Dollabella.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: He's now in Caesar's Camp.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No matter where,
Since he's no longer mine. He took unkindly
That I forbad him Cleopatra's sight;
Because I fear'd he lov'd her: he confess'd
He had a warmth, which, for my sake, he stifled;
For 'twere impossible that two, so one,
Should not have lov'd the same. When he departed,
He took no leave; and that confirm'd my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: It argues that he lov'd you more than her,
•… lse he had staid; but he perceiv'd you jealous,
And would not grieve his Friend: I know he love you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I should have seen him then ere now.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Perhaps
He has thus long been lab'ring for your Peace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Would he were here.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Would you believe he lov'd you?
I read your Answer in your Eyes; you would.
Not to conceal it longer, he has sent
A Messenger from Caesar's Camp, with Letters.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let him appear.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I'll bring him instantly.
sp.stage: Exit Ventidius, and Re-enters immediately with Dollabella.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis he himself, himself, by holy Friendship
Art thou return'd at last, my better half?
Come, give me all my self.
Let me not live,
If the young Bridegroom, Ionging for his Night,
Was ever half so fond.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I must be silent; for my Soul is busie
About a noble Work: she's new come home,
Like a long absent Man, and wanders o'er
Each Room, a Stranger to her own, to loo •…
If all be safe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou hast what's left of m •…
For I am now so sunk from what I was,
Thou find'st me at my lowest Water-mark.
The Rivers that ran in, and rais'd my Fortunes,
Are all dry'd up, or take another course:
What I have left is from my native Spring;
I've still a Heart that swells, in scorn of Fate.
And lifts me to my Banks.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Still you are Lord of all the World to me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why, then I yet am so; for thou art all.
If I had any Joy when thou wert absent,
I grudg'd it to my self; methought I robb'd
Thee of thy part. But, Oh my Dollabella!
Thou hast beheld me other than I am.
Hast thou not seen my morning Chambers fill'd
With Sc •… pter'd Slaves, who waited to salute me:
With Eastern Monarchs, who forgot the Sun,
To worship my uprising? Menial Kings
Ran coursing up and down my Palace-yard,
Stood silent in my Presence, watch'd my Eyes,
And, at my least Command, all started out
Like Racers to the Gaol.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Slaves to your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fortune is Caesar's now; and what am I?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What you have made your self; I will not flatter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is this friendly done?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Yes, when his end is so, I must join with him;
Indeed I must, and yet you must not chide:
Why am I else your Friend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Take heed, young Ma •… ,
How thou upbraid'st my Love: The Queen has Eyes,
And thou too hast a Soul. Canst thou remember
When, swell'd with hatred, thou beheld'st her first
As Accessary to thy Brothers Death?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Spare my Remembrance; 'twas a guilty day,
And still the blush hangs here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To clear her self,
For sending him no Aid, she came from Egypt.
Her Gally down the Silver Cydnos row'd,
The Tackling Silk, the Streamers wav'd with Gold,
The gentle Winds were lodg'd in Purple Sails:
Her Nymphs, like Nereids, round her Couch, were plac'd;
Where she, another Sea-born Venus, lay.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: No more: I would not hear it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, you must!
She lay, and leant her Cheek upon her Hand,
And cast a Look so languishingly sweet,
As if, secure of all Beholders Hearts,
Neglecting she could take 'em: Boy's, like Cupids,
Stood fanning, with their painted Wings, the Winds
That plaid about her Face: But if she smil'd,
A darting Glory seem'd to blaze abroad:
That Mens desiring Eyes were never weary'd;
But hung upon the Object: To soft Flutes
The Silver Oars kept Time; and while they plaid,
The Hearing gave new Pleasure to the Sight;
And both to Thought: 'twas Heav'n or somewhat more;
For she so charm'd all Hearts, that gazing Crowds
Stood panting on the shore, and wanted Breath
To give their welcome Voice.
Then, Dollabella, where was then thy Soul?
Was not thy Fury quite disarm'd with Wonder?
Didst tho •… not shrink behind me from those Eyes,
And whisper in my Ears? Oh, tell her not
That I accus'd her wi •… h my Brothers Death!

sp.speaker: Dolla
sp.l: And should my Weakness be a Plea fer yours?
Mine was an Age when Love might be excus'd,
When kindly war •… th, and when my springing youth
Made it a Debt to Nature. Yours—

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Speak boldly.
Yours, he would say; in your declining Age,
When no more heat was left but what you forc'd,
When all the Sap was needful for the Trunk,
When it went down, then you constrain'd the Course,
And robb'd from Nature, to supply Desire;
In you (I would not use so harsh a Word)
But 'tis plain Dotage.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Dolla
sp.l: 'Twas urg'd too home.
But yet the loss was private that I made;
'Twas but my self I lost: I lost no Legions;
I had no World to lose, no Peoples Love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This from a Friend?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Yes, Anthony, a true one;
A Friend so tender, that each Word I speak
Stabs my own Heart, before it reach your Ear.
O, judge me not less kind because I chide:
To Caesar I excuse you.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.l: O ye Gods!
Have I then liv'd to be excus'd to Caesar?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: As to your Equal:
While I wear this, he never shall be more.

sp.speaker: Dolla
sp.l: I bring Conditions from him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are they Noble?
Methinks thou shouldst not bring 'em else; yet he
Is sull of deep dissembling; knows no Honour,
Divided from his Int'rest. Fate mistook him;
For Nature meant him for an Usurer,
He's fit indeed to buy, not conquer Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Then, granting this,
What Pow'r was theirs who wrought so hard a Temper
To honourable Terms!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It was my Dollabella, or some God.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Nor I; nor yet Mecoenas, nor Agrippa:
They were your Enemies; and I a Friend
Too weak alone; yet 'twas a Roman's Deed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Twas like a Roman done: show me that Man
Who has preserv'd my Life, my Love, my Honour;
Let me but see his Face.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: That task is mine,
And, Hea •… 'n thou know'st how pleasing.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: You'll remember
To whom you stand oblig'd?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When I forget it,
Be thou unkind, and that's my greatest curse.
My Queen shall thank him too.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I fear she will not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But she shall do't: the Queen, my Dollabella!
Hast thou not still some grudgings of thy Fever?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I would not see her lost.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wh •… n I sorsake her,
Leave me, my be •… ter Sta •… s; f •… r she has truth
Beyond her beauty. Caesar tempted her,
At no less price than Kingdoms, to betray me;
But she resisted all: and yet thou chid'st me
For loving her too well. Could I do so?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Yes there's my reason.
sp.stage: Re-enter Ventidius, with Octavia, leading Antony's two little Daughters.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where?—Octavia there!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What, is she poyson to you? a Disease?
Look on her, view her well; and those she brings:
Are they all Strangers to your eyes? has Nature
No secret Call, no whisper they are yours?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: For shame, my Lord, if not for Love, receive 'em
With kinder Eyes. If you confess a Man,
Meet 'em, embrace 'em, bid 'em welcome to you.
Your Arms should open, ev'n without; your knowledge,
To clasp 'em in; your Feet should turn to Wings,
To bear you to 'em; and your Eyes dart out,
And aim a kiss ere you could reach the Lips.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I stood amaz'd to think how they came hither.

sp.speaker: Vent.
sp.l: I sent for 'em; I brought 'em in, unknown
To Cleopatra's Guards.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Yet are you cold?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Thus long I have attended for my welcome;
Which, as a Stranger, sure I might expect,
Who am I?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Caesar's Sister.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: That's unkind!
Had I been nothing more than Caesar's Sister,
Know, I had still remain'd in Caesar's Camp;
But you Octavi •… , your much injur'd Wise,
Tho' banish'd from your Bed, driv'n from your House,
In spight of Caesar's Sister, still is yours.
'Tis true, I have a heart disdains your Coldness,
And prompts me not to seek what you should offer;
But a Wife's Virtue still surmounts that Pride:
I come to claim you as my own; to show
My Duty first, to ask, nay beg, your kindness:
Your hand, my Lord; 'tis mine, and I will have it.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Do, take it, thou deserv'st it.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: On my Soul,
And so she does: she's neither too submissive,
Nor yet too haughty; but so just a mean,
Shows, as it ought, a Wife and Roman too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I •… ear, Octavia, you have begg'd my Life.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Begg'd it, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, begg'd it, my Ambassadress,
Poorly and basely begg'd it of your Brother.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Poorly and bafely I could never beg;
Nor could my Brother grant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shall I, who, to my kneeling Slave, could say,
Rise up, and be a King; shall I fall down
And cry, Forgive me, Caesar? shall I set
A Man, my Equal, in the place of Jove,
As he could give me being? No; that word,
Forgive, would choak me up,
And die upon my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: You shall not need it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will not need it. Come, you've all betray'd me:
My Friend too! To receive some vile Conditions.
My Wife has bought me, with her Prayers and Tears;
And now I must become her branded Slave:
In every peevish Mood she will upbraid
The Life she gave: if I but look awry,
She cries, I'll tell my Brother.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: My hard Fortune
Subjects me still to your unkind mistakes.
But the Conditions I have brought are such
You need not blush to take: I love your Honour,
Because 'tis mine; it never shall be said
Octavia's Husband was her Brothers Slave.
Sir, you are Free; Free, ev'n from her you loath;
For, tho' my Brother bargains for your Love,
Makes me the Price and Cement of your Peace,
I have a Soul like yours; I cannot take
Your Love as Alms, nor beg what I deserve.
I'll tell my Brother we are reconcil'd;
He shall draw back his Troops, and you shall march
To rule the East: I may be dropt at Athens;
No matter where, I never will complain,
But only keep the barren Name of Wife,
And rid you of the trouble.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Was ever such a strife of sullen Honour!
Both scorn'd to be oblig'd.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Oh, she has toucht him in the tender'st part;
S •… e how he reddens with despight and shame
To be out-done in Generosity!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: See how he winks! how he dries up a Tear,
That fain would fall!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Octavia, I have heard you, and must praise
The greatness of your Soul;
But cannot yield to what you have propos'd:
For I can ne'er be conquer'd but by Love;
A •… d you do all for Duty. You would free me,
And would be dropt at Athens; was't not so?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: It was, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then I must be oblig'd
To one who Loves me not, who, to her self,
May call me thankless and ungrateful Man:
I'll not endure it, no.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I'm glad it pinches there.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Would you triumph o'er poor Octavia's Virtue?
That Pride was all I had to bear me up;
That you might think you ow'd me for your Life,
And ow'd it to my Duty, not my Love.
I have been injur'd, and my haughty Soul
Could brook but ill the Man who slights my Bed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Therefore you Love me not.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Therefore, my Lord,
I should not love you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Therefore you wou'd leave me?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: And therefore I should leave you—if I could.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Her Soul's too great, after such injuries,
To say she Loves; and yet she lets you see it.
Her modesty and silence plead her Cause.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh, Dollabella, which way shall I turn?
I find a secret yielding in my Soul;
But Cleopatra, who would die with me,
Must she be left? Pity pleads for Octavia;
But does it not plead more for Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Justice and Pity both plead for Octavia;
For Cleopatra, neither.
One would be ruin'd with you; but she first
Had ruin'd you: the other, you have ruin'd,
And yet she would preserve you.
In every thing their Merits are unequal.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh, my distracted Soul!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Sweet Heav'n compose it.
Come, come, my Lord, if I can pardon you,
Methinks you should accept it. Look on these;
Are they not yours? Or stand they thus neglected
As they are mine? Go to him, Children, go;
Kneel to him, take him by the hand, speak to him;
For you may speak, and he may own you too,
Without a Blush; and so he cannot all
His Children: go, I say, and pull him to me,
And pull him to your selves, from that bad Woman.
You, Agrippina, hang upon his Arms;
And you, Antonia, clasp about his Waste:
If he will shake you off, if he will dash you
Against the Pavement, you must bear it, Children;
For you are mine, and I was born to suffer.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Was ever sight so moving! Emperor!

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Friend!

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Husband!

sp.speaker: Both Childr.
sp.l: Father!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am vanquish'd: take me,
Octavia; take me, Children; share me all.
I've been a thriftless Debtor to your Loves,
And run out much, in Riot, from your Stock;
But all shall be amended.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: O blest hour!

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: O happy Change!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: My joy stops at my tongue;
But it has found two Channels here for one,
And Bubbles out above.

sp.speaker: Ant. to Octav.
sp.l: This is thy Triumph; lead me where thou wilt;
Ev'n to thy Brothers Camp.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: All there are yours.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The Queen, my Mistress, Sir, and yours—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis past. Octavia, you shall stay this night; To morrow,
Caesar and we are one.
sp.stage: [Ex. leading Octavia, Doll. and the Children follow.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: There's News for you; run,
My officious Eunuch,
Be sure to be the first; haste forward:
Haste, my dear Eunuch, haste.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: This downright fighting Fool, this thick-scull'd Hero,
This blunt unthinking Instrument of Death,
With plain dull Virtue, has out-gone my Wit:
Pleasure forsook my early'st Infancy,
The Luxury of others robb'd my Cradle,
And ravish'd thence the Promise of a Man:
Cast out from Nature, disinherited
Of what her meanest Children claim by kind;
Yet, Greatness kept me from Contempt: that's gone.
Had Cleopatra follow'd my advice,
Then he had been betray'd, who now forsakes.
She dies for love; but she has known its joys:
Gods, is this just, that I, who knows no joys,
Must die, because she loves?
Oh, Madam, I have seen what blasts my Eyes!
Octavia's here!

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Peace with that Raven's note.
I know it too; and now am in
The Pangs of Death.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: You are no more a Queen;
Egypt is lost.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: What tell'st thou me of Egypt?
My Life, my Soul is lost! Octavia has him!
O fatal Name to Cleopatra's love!
My kisses, my embraces now are hers;
While I—But thou hast seen my Rival; speak,
Does she deserve this Blessing? Is she fair,
Bright as a Goddess? and is all perfection
Confin'd to her? It is. Poor I was made
Of that course matter which, when she was finish'd,
The Gods threw by, for rubbish.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: She's indeed a very Miracle.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Death to my hopes, a Miracle!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: A Miracle;
I mean of Goodness; for in Beauty, Madam,
You make all Wonders cease.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I was too rash:
Take this in part of recompence. But, Oh,
I fear thou flatter'st me.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: She comes! she's here!

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Flie, Madam, Caesar s Sister!

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Were she the Sister of the Thund'rer Jove,
And bore her Brother's Lightning in her Eyes,
Thus would I face my Rival.
sp.stage: [Meets Octav. with Ventid. Octav. bears up to her. Their Trains come up on either side.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: I need not ask if you are Cleopatra,
Your haughty Carriage—

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Shows I am a Queen:
Nor need I ask you who you are.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: A Roman:
A Name that makes, and can unmake a Queen.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Your Lord, the Man who serves me, is a Roman.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: He was a Roman, till he lost that Name
To be a Slave in Egypt; but I come
To free him thence.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Peace, peace, my Lover's Juno.
When he grew weary of that Houshold-Clog,
He chose my easier Bonds.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: I wonder not
Your Bonds are easie; you have long been practis'd
In that lascivious Art: he's not the first
For whom you spread your snares: let Caesar witness.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I lov'd not Caesar; 'twas but gratitude
I paid his Love: the worst your Malice can,
Is but to say the greatest of Mankind
Has been my Slave. The next, but far above him,
In my Esteem, is he whom Law calls yours,
But whom his Love made mine.
sp.stage: Oct. coming up close to her.
sp.l: I would view nearer
That Face, which has so long usurp'd my right,
To find th' inevitable Charms, that catch
Mankind so sure, that ruin'd my dear Lord.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: O, you do well to search; for had you known
But half these Charms, you had not lost his heart.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Far be their knowledge from a Roman Lady,
Far from a modest Wife. Shame of our Sex,
Dost thou not Blush, to own those black Endearments
That make sin pleasing?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: You may Blush, who want 'em: if bounteous Nature, if indulgent Heav'n
Have giv'n me Charms to please the bravest Man;
Should I not thank 'em? should I be asham'd,
And not be Proud? I am, that he has lov'd me;
And, when I love not him, Heav'n change this Face
For one like that.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Thou lov'st him not so well.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I Love him better, and deserve him more.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: You do not; cannot: you have been his ruine.
W •… o made him cheap at Rome, but Cleopatra?
Who made him scorn'd abroad, but Cleopatra?
At Actium, who betray'd him? Cleopatra.
Who made his Children Orphans? and poor me
A wretched Widow? only Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Yet she who loves him best is Cleopatra.
If you have suffer'd, I have suffer'd more.
You bear the specious Title of a Wife,
To gild your Cause, and draw the pitying World
To favour it: the World contemns poor me;
For I have lost my Honour, lost my Fame,
And stain'd the Glory of my Royal House,
And all to bear the branded Name of Mistress.
There wants but Life, and that too I would lose
For him I love.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Be't so then; take thy Wish.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: And 'tis my Wish,
Now he is lost for whom alone I liv'd.
My sight grows dim, and every Object dances,
And swims before me, in the maze of Death.
My Spirits, while they were oppos'd, kept up;
They could not sink beneath a Rivals scorn:
But now she's gone they faint.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Mine have had leisure
To recollect their Strength, and furnish Counsel,
To ruine her; who else must ruine you.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Vain Promiser!
Lead me, my Charmion; nay, your hand too, Iras:
My Grief has weight enough to sink you both.
Conduct me to some Solitary Chamber,
And draw the Curtains round;
Then leave me to my self, to take alone
My fill of Grief:
There I till Death will his unkindness weep:
As harmless Infants moan themselves asleep.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: WHy would you shift it from your self, on me?
Can you not tell her you must part?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I cannot,
I could pull out an Eye, and bid it go,
And t'other should not weep. Oh, Dollabella,
How many Deaths are in this word Depart!
I dare not trust my tongue to tell her so:
One Look of hers, would thaw me into Tears,
And I should melt till I were lost agen.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Then let Ventidius;
He's rough by Nature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh, he'll speak too harshly;
He'll kill her with the News: Thou, only thou.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Nature has cast me in so soft a Mould,
That but to hear a Story feign'd for Pleasure
Of some sad Lovers Death, moistens my Eyes,
And robs me of my Manhood.—I should speak
So faintly; with such fear to grieve her Heart,
She'd not believe it earnest.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Therefore; therefore
Thou only, thou art fit: think thy self me,
And when thou speak'st (but let it first be long)
Take off the edge from every Sharper sound,
And let our parting be as gently made
As other Loves begin: wilt thou do this?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: What you have said, so sinks into my Soul,
That, if I must speak, I shall speak just so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I leave you then to your sad task: Farewel.
I sent her word to meet you.
sp.stage: (Goes to the door, and comes back.)
sp.l: I forgot;
Let her be told, I'll make her peace with mine:
Her Crown and Dignity shall be preserv'd,
If I have pow'r with Caesar.—O, be sure
To think on that.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Fear not, I will remember.
sp.stage: [Ant •… ny goes agi •… to the door, and c •… mes back.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And tell her, too, how much I was constrain'd;
I did not this, but with extreamest force:
D •… sire her not to hate my Memory,
For I still cherish hers;—insist on that.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Trust me, I'll not forget it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then that's all.
Wilt thou forgive my fondness this once more?
Tell her, tho' we shall never meet again,
If I should hear she took another Love,
The News would break my Heart.—Now I must go;
For every time I have return'd, I feel
My Soul more tender; and my next Command
Would be to bid her stay, and ruine both.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Men are but Children of a larger growth,
Our Appetites as apt to change as theirs,
And full as craving too, and full as vain;
And yet the Soul, shut up in her dark Room,
Viewing so clear abroad, at home sees nothing;
But, like a Mole in Earth, busie and blind,
Works all her folly up, and casts it outward
To the Worlds open view: thus I discover'd,
And blam'd the Love of ruin'd Antony;
Yet wish that I were he, to be so ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Alone? and Talking to himself? concern'd too?
Perhaps my Guess is right; he lov'd her once,
And may pursue it still.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: O Friendship! Friendship!
Ill canst thou answer this; and Reason, worse:
Unfaithful in th' Attempt; hopeless to win;
And, if I win, undone: mere madness all.
And yet th' occasion's fair. What injury,
To him, to wear the Robe which he throws by?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: None, none at all. This happens as I wish,
To ruine her yet more with Antony.
sp.stage: Enter Cleopatra, talking with Alexas, Charmion, Iras on the other side.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: She comes! What Charms have sorrow on that Face!
Sorrow seems pleas'd to dwell with so much sweetness;
Yet, now and then, a Melancholy smile
Breaks loose, like Lightning, in a Winter's night,
And shows a moments day.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: If she should love him too! Her Eunuch there!
That Porcpisce bodes ill weather. Draw, draw nearer,
Sweet Devil, that I may hear.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Believe me; try
sp.stage: [Dollabella goes over to Charmi •… n and Iras; seems to talk with them.
sp.l: To make him jealous; jealousie is like
A polisht Glass held to the lips when Life's in doubt:
If there be Breath, 'twill catch the damp and show it.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I grant you Jealousie's a Proof of Love,
But 'tis a weak and unavailing Med'cine;
It puts out the Disease, and makes it show,
But has no pow'r to cure.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: 'Tis your last Remedy, and strongest too:
And then this Dollabella, who so fit
To practice on? He's handsome, valiant, young,
And looks as he were laid for Nature's bait
To catch weak Womens Eyes.
He stands already more than half suspected
Of loving you: the least kind word, or glance,
You give this Youth, will kindle him with Love:
Then, like a burning Vessel set adrift,
You'll send him down amain before the Wind,
To fire the Heart of jealous Antony.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Can I do this? Ah no; my Love's so true,
That I can neither hide it where it is,
Nor show it where it is not. Nature meant me
A Wife, a silly harmless houshold Dove,
Fond without Art; and kind without Deceit;
But Fortune, that has made a Mistress of me,
Hast thrust me out to the wide World, unfurnish'd
Of falshood to be happy.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Force your self.
Th' event wil be, your Lover will return
Doubly desirous to possess the good
Which once he •… ar'd to lose.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I must Attempt it;
But Oh with what regret!
sp.stage: Exit. Alex. (She comes up to Dollabella.)

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: So, now the Scene draws near; they're in my reach.

sp.speaker: Cleop. to Dol.
sp.l: Discoursing with my Women! Might not I
Share in your Entertainment?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: You have been
The Subject of it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: How; and how?

sp.speaker: •… as.
sp.l: Such praises of your Beauty!

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Mere Poetry.
Your Roman Wits, your Gallus and Tibullus,
Have taught you this •… rom Citheris and Delia.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Those Roman Wits have never been in Egypt,
Citheris and Delia else had been unsung:
I, who have seen—had I been born a Poet,
Should chuse a nobler Name.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: You flatter me.
But, 'tis your Nation's vice: all of your Country
Are flatterers, and all false. Your Friend's like you.
I'm sure he sent you not to speak these words.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: No, Madam; yet he sent me—

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Well, he sent you—

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Of a less pleasing Errand.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: How less pleasing?
Less to you self, or me?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Madam, to both;
For you must mourn, and I must grieve to cause it.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: You, Charmion, and your Fellow, stand at distance.
Hold up, my Spirits.—Well, now your mournful matter;
For I'm prepar'd, perhaps can Guess it too.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I wish you would; for 'tis a thankless office
To tell ill News: and I, of all your Sex,
Most fear displeasing you.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Of all your Sex,
I soonest could forgive you, if you should.

sp.speaker: Ven
sp.l: Most delicate advances! Woman! Woman!
Dear damn'd, inconstant Sex!

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: In the first place,
I am to be forsaken; is't not so?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I wish I could not Answer to that Question.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Then pass it o'er, because it troubles you:
I should have been more griev'd another time.
Next, I'm to lose my Kingdom.—Farewel, Egypt.
Yet, is there any more?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Madam, I fear
Your too deep Sense of Grief has turn'd your Reason.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: No, no, I'm not run mad; I can bear Fortune:
And Love may be expell'd by other Love,
As Poysons are by Poysons.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: —You o'erjoy me, Madam,
To find your Griefs so moderately born.
You've heard the worst; all are not false, like him.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: No; Heav'n forbid they should.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Some Men are constant.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: And Constancy deserves Reward, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Deserves it not; but give it leave to hope.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I'll swear thou hast my leave. I have enough:
But how to manage this! Well, I'll consider.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I came prepar'd,
To tell you heavy News; News, which I thought,
Would fright the Blood from your pale Cheeks to hear:
But you have met it with a Cheerfulness
That makes my Task more easie; and my Tongue,
Which on anothers Message was employ'd,
Would gladly speak its own.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Hold, Dollabella.
First tell me, were you chosen by my Lord?
Or sought you this Employment?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: He pick'd me out; and, as his Bosom-Friend,
He Charg'd me with his words.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: The Message then
I know was tender, and each Accent smooth,
To molli •… e that rugged word Depart.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Oh, you mistake: he chose the harshest words,
With fiery Eyes, and with contracted Brows,
He Coyn'd his Face in the severest stamp:
And fury shook his Fabrick like an Earthquake;
He heav'd for vent, and burst like bellowing Aetna,
In Sounds scarce humane, "Hence, away for ever:
"Let her be gone, the blot of my renown,
"And bane of all my hopes:
sp.stage: [All the time of this Speech, Cleop. seems more and more concern'd, till she sinks quite down.
sp.l: "Let her be driv'n a •… far as Men can think
"From Mans commerce: She'll poyson to the Center.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Oh, I can bear no more!

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Help, help: Oh Wretch! Oh cursed, cursed Wretch!
What have I done?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Help, chafe her Temples, Iras.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Bend, bend her forward quickly.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Heav'n be prais'd,
She comes again.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Oh, let him not approach me.
Why have you brought me back to this loath'd Being,
Th' abode of Falshood, violated Vows,
And injur'd Love? For Pity, let me go;
For, if there be a place of long repose,
I'm sure I want it. My disdainful Lord
Can never break that quiet; nor awake
The sleeping Soul, with hollowing in my Tomb
Such words as fright her hence, Unkind, unkind.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Believe me, 'tis against my self I speak,
That sure deserves Belief; I inju •… 'd him:
My Friend ne'er spoke those words. Oh, had you seen
How often he came back, and every time
With something more obliging and more kind,
To add to what he said; what dear Farewels;
How almost vanquisht by his Love he parted,
And lean'd to what unwillingly he left:
I, Traitor as I was, for love of you,
(But what can you not do, who made me false!)
I forg'd that Lye; for whose forgiveness kneels
This self-accus'd, self-punish'd Criminal.

sp.speaker: Cleop
sp.l: With how much ease believe we what we wish!
Rise, D •… llabella; if you have been Guilty,
I have contributed, and too much Love
Has made me Guilty too.
Th' advance of kindness which I made, was feign'd,
To call back fleeting Love by Jealousie;
But 'twould not last. Oh, rather let me lose
Than so ignobly trifle with his heart.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I find your Breast fenc'd round from humane reach,
Transparent as a Rock of solid Chrystal;
Seen through, but never pierc'd. My Friend, my Friend!
What endless Treasure hast thou thrown away,
And scatter'd, like an Infant, in the Ocean,
Vain sums of Wealth which none can gather thence.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Could you not beg
An hours Admittance to his private Ear?
Like one who wanders through long barren Wilds,
And yet foreknows no Hospitable Inn.
Is near to succour Hunger,
Eats his fill, before his painful March:
So would I feed a while my famish'd Eyes
B for •… we part; for I have far to go,
If Death be far, and never must return.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: From hence you may discover—Oh, sweet, sweet!
Would you indeed? the pretty hand in Earnest?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I will, for this Reward.—Draw it not back,
'Tis all I e'er will beg.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: They turn upon us.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: What quick Eyes has Guilt!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Seem not to have observ'd 'em, and go on.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Saw you the Emperor, Ventidius? Ven. No.
I sought him; but I heard that he was private,
None with him, but Hipparchus his Freedman.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Know you his bus'ness?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Giving him Instructions,
And Letters, to his Brother C •… r.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Well,
He must be found.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Most glorious impudence!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: She look'd methought
As she would say, Take your old Man, Octavia;
Thank you, I'm better here.
Well, but what use
Make we of this Discovery?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Let it die.

sp.speaker: Ven
sp.l: I pity Dollabella; but she's dangerous:
Her Eyes have pow'r beyond Thessalian Charms
To draw the Moon from Heav'n; for Eloquence,
The Sea-green Syrens taught her Voice their flatt'ry;
And, while she speaks, Night steals upon the Day,
Unmark'd of those that hear: Then she's so charming,
Age buds at sight of her, and swells to youth:
The holy Priests gaze on her when she smiles;
And with heav'd hands forgetting Gravity,
They bless her wanton Eyes: Even I who hate her,
With a malignant joy behold such Beauty;
And, while I Curse, desire it. Anthony
Must needs have some remains of Passion still,
Which may ferment into a worse Relapse,
If now no •… fully cur'd. I know, this minute,
With C •… sar he's endeavouring her Peace.

sp.speaker: Octav
sp.l: You have prevail'd:—but for a farther purpose Walks off.
I'll prove how he will relish this Discovery.
What, make a S •… rumpet's peace: it swells my Heart:
It must not, •… na' not be

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: His Guards appear.
Let me begin, and you shall second me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Octavia, I was looking you, my Love:
What, are your Letters ready? I have giv'n
My last Instructions.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Mine, my Lord, are written.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A word in private.
When saw you Dollabella?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now, my Lord,
He parted hence; and Cleopatra with him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speak softly. 'Twas by my Command he went,
To bear my last farewel.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: It look'd indeed
Like your farewel.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: More softly.—My farewel?
What secret meaning have you in those words
Of my Farewel? He did it by my Order.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Then he obey'd your Order. I suppose
You bid him do it with all Gentleness,
All kindness, and all—love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How she mourn'd,
The poor forsaken Creature!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: She took it as she ought; she bore your parting
As she did Caesar's, as she would anothers,
Were a new Love to come.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou dost belye her;
Most basely, and maliciously belye her.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I thought not to displease you; I have done.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: You seem disturb'd, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A very trifle.
Retire, my Love.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: It was indeed a trifle.
He sent—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more. Look how thou disobey'st me;
Thy Life shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Then 'tis no trifle.

sp.speaker: Ven. to Octav.
sp.l: 'Tis less; a very nothing: you too saw it,
As well as I, and therefore 'tis no Secret.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She saw it!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Yes: she saw young Dollabella—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Young Dollabella!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Young, I think him young,
And handsom too; and so do others think him.
But what of that? He went by your Command,
Indeed 'tis probable, with some kind Message;
For she receiv'd it graciously; she smil'd:
And then he grew familiar with her Hand,
Squeez'd it, and worry'd it with ravenous Kisses;
She blush'd, and sigh'd, and smil'd, and blush'd again;
At last she took occasion to Talk softly,
And brought her Cheek up close, and lean'd on his:
At which, he whisper'd Kisses back on hers;
And then she cry'd aloud, That Constancy
Should be rewarded.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: This I saw and heard.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What Womam was it, whom you heard and saw
So playful with my Friend!
Not Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Ev'n she, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Cleopatra?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Your Cleopatra;
Dollabella's Cleopatra?
Every Man's Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tou •… t.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I do not lye, my Lord.
Is this so strange? should Mistresses be left,
And not provide against a time of Change?
You know she's not much us'd to lonely Nights.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll think no more on't.
I know 'tis false, and see the Plot betwixt you.
You needed not have gone this way, Octavia.
What harms it you that Cleopatra's just?
She's mine no more. I see; and I forgive:
Urge it no farther, Love.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Are you concern'd
That she's found false?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I should be, were it so;
For, tho 'tis past, I would not that the World
Should Tax my former Choice: That I lov'd one
Of so light Note; but I forgive you both.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What has my Age deserv'd, that you should think
I would abuse your Ears with Perjury?
If Heav'n be true, she's false.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tho Heav'n and 'Earth
Should witness it, I'll not believe her tainted.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I'll bring you then a Witness
From Hell to prove her so. Nay, go not back;
sp.stage: [Seeing Alexas just entring, and starting back.
sp.l: For stay you must and shall.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: What means my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: To make you do what most you hate; speak truth.
You are of Cleopatra's private Counsel,
Of her Bed-Counsel, her lascivious hours;
Are conscious of each Nightly change she makes,
And watch her, as Chaldeans do the Moon,
Can tell what Signs she passes through, what day.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: My Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: My most Illustrious Pandar,
No fine set Speech, no Cadence, to turn'd Periods,
But a pla •… home-spun Truth, is what I ask:
I did, my self, o'er hear your Queen make love
To Dollabella. Speak; for I will know,
By your Confession, what more past betwixt 'em;
How near the bus'ness draws to your Employment;
And when the happy hour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speak truth, Alexas, whether it offend
Or please Ventidius, care not: justifie
Thy injur'd Queen from Malice: dare his worst.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: See how he gives him Courage! how he fears
To find her false! and shuts his Eyes to truth,
Willing to be mi •… ed!

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: As far as love may plead for Woman's frailty,
U g'd by desert and greatness of the Lover;
So far (Divine Octavia!) may my Queen
Stand ev •… excus'd to yo •… , for loving him,
Who is your Lord: so far, from brave Venttdius,
May her past Actions hope a fair Report.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tis well, and truly spoken: mark, Ventidius.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: To you, most Noble Emperor, her strong Passion
Stands not excus'd, but wholly justifi'd.
Her Beauty's Charms alone, without her Crown,
From Ind and Meroe drew the distant Vows
Of sighing Kings; and at her Feet were laid
The Scepters of the Earth, expos'd on heaps,
To choose where she would Reign:
She thought a Roman only could deserve her;
And, of all Romans, only Antony.
And, to be l •… ss than Wife to you, disdain'd
Their lawful Passion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis but Truth.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And yet, tho' Love, and your unmatch'd Desert,
Have drawn her from the due regard of Honor,
At last, Heav'n open'd her unwilling Eyes
To see the wrongs she offer'd fair Octavia,
Whose holy Bed she lawfully usurpt,
The sad Effects of this improsperous War,
Confirm'd those pious Thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: O, wheel you there?
Observe him now; the Man begins to mend,
And Talk substantial Reason. Fear not, Eunuch,
The Emperor has giv'n thee leave to speak.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Else had I never dar'd t' offend his Ears
With what the last necessity has urg'd
On my forsaken Mistress; yet I must not
Presume to say her Heart is wholly alter'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, dare not for thy Life, I Charge thee dare not,
Pronounce that fatal word.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Must I bear this? good Heav'n, afford me patience.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: On, sweet Eunuch; my dear half Man, proceed.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Yet Dollabella
Has lov'd her long, he, next my God-like Lord,
Deserves her best; and should she meet his Passion,
Rejected, as she is, by him she lov'd——

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hence, from my sight; for I can bear no more:
Let Furies drag thee quick to Hell; each torturing hand
Do thou employ, till Cleopatra comes,
Then joyn thou too, and help to torture her.
sp.stage: Exit Alexas, thrust out by Antony.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: 'Tis not well,
Indeed, my Lord, 'tis much unkind to me,
To show this Passion, this extreme Concernment
For an abandon'd, faithless Prostitute.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Octavia, leave me: I am much disorder'd.
Leave me, I say.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I bid you leave me.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Obey him, Madam: best withdraw a while,
And see how this will work.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Wherein have I offended you, my Lord,
That I am bid to leave you? Am I false,
Or infamous? Am I a Cleopatra?
Were I she,
Base as she is, you would not bid me leave you;
But hang upon my Neck, take slight Excuses,
And fawn upon my Falshood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis too much,
Too much, Octavia; I am prest with Sorrows
Too heavy to be born; and you add more:
I would retire, and recollect what's left
Of Man within, to aid me.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: You would mourn
In private, for your Love, who has betray'd you;
You did but half return to me: your kindness
Linger'd behind with her. I hear, my Lord,
You make Conditions for her,
And would include her Treaty. Wondrous proofs
Of Love to me!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are you my Friend, Ventidius?
Or are you turn'd a Dollabella too,
And let this Fury loose?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Oh, be advis'd,
Sweet Madam, and retire.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Yes, I will go; but never to return.
You shall no more be haunted with this Fury.
My Lord, my Lord, Love will not always last,
When urg'd with long unkindness, and disdain;
Take her again whom you perfer to me;
She stays but to be call'd. Poor cozen'd Man!
Let a feign'd parting give her back your Heart,
Which a feign'd Love first got; for injur'd me,
Tho my just Sense of wrongs forbid my stay,
My Duty shall be yours.
To the dear Pledges of our former Love,
My tenderness and care shall be transferr'd,
And they shall Cheer, by Turns, my Widow'd Nights:
So, take my last farewel; for I despair
To have you whole, and scorn to take you half.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I combat Heav'n, which blasts my best Designs:
My last Attempt must be to win her back;
But Oh, I fear in vain.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why was I fram'd with this plain honest Heart,
Which knows not to disguise its Griefs, and Weakness,
But bears its workings outward to the World?
I should have kept the mighty Anguish in,
And forc'd a Smile at Cleopatra's falshood:
Octavia had believ'd it, and had staid;
But I am made a shallow-forded Stream,
Seen to the Bottom: all my clearness scorn'd,
And all my Faults expos'd!—See, where he comes
Who has prophan'd the Sacred Name of Friend,
And worn it into Vileness!
With how secure a Brow, and specious Form
He gilds the secret Villain! Sure that Face
Was meant for Honesty; but Heav'n mis-match'd it,
And furnish'd Treason out with Natures Pomp,
To make its work more easie.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: O, my Friend!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, Dollabella, you perform'd my Message?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I did, unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Unwillingly?
Was it so hard for you to bear our parting?
You should have wisht it.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Because you love me.
And she receiv'd my Message, with as true,
With as unfeign'd a Sorrow, as you brought it?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: She loves you, ev'n to madness.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh, I know it.
You, Dollabella, do not better know
How much she loves me. And should I
Forsake this Beauty? This all-perfect Creature?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I could not, were she mine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And yet you first
Perswaded me: how come you alter'd since?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: I said at first I was not fit to go;
I could not hear her sighs, and see her tears,
But Pity must prevail: and so, perhaps,
It may again with you; for I have promis'd
That she should take her last farewel: and, see,
She comes to claim my word.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: False Dollabella!

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: What's false, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why, Dollabella's false;
And Cleopatra's false; both false and faithless.
Draw near, you well-joyn'd wickedness, you Serpents,
Whom I have, in my kindly Bosom, warm
Till I am stung to Death.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: My Lord, have I
Deserv'd to be thus us'd?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Can Heav'n prepare
A newer Torment? Can it find a Curse
Beyond our Separation?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, if Fate
Be just, much greater: Heav'n should be ingenious
In punishing such Crimes. The rowling Stone,
And gnawing Vulture, we slight Pains, invented
When Jove was young, and no Examples known
Of mighty Ills; but you have ripen'd sin
To such a monstrous growth, 'twill pose the Gods
To find an equal Torture. Two, two such,
Oh there's no farther Name, two such—to me,
To me, who lock'd my Soul within your Breasts,
Had no Desires, no Joys, no Life, but you;
When half the Globe was mine, I gave it you
In Dowry with my Heart; I had no use,
No fruit of all, but you: a Friend and Mistress
Was what the World could give. Oh, Cleopatra!
Oh, Dollabella! how could you betray
This tender Hea •… t, which with an Infant-fondness.
Lay lull'd betwixt your Bosoms, and there slept
Secure of injur'd Faith?

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: If she has wrong'd you,
Heav'n, Hell, and You revenge it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If she wrong'd me,
Thou wouldst evade thy part of Guilt; but swear
Thou lov'st not her.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Not so as I love you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not so! Swear, swear, I say; thou dost not love her;

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: No more than Friendship will allow.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more?
Friendship allows thee nothing: thou art perjur'd.—
And yet thou didst not swear thou lov'dst her not;
But 〈◊〉 so much, no more. Oh trifling Hypocrite,
Who dar'st not own to her thou dost not love,
Not own to me thou dost! Ventidius heard it;
Octavia saw it.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: They are Enemies.

sp.speaker: Ant
sp.l: Alexas Is not so: he, he confest it.
He, who, next Hell, best knew it, he avow'd it.
Why do I seek a Proof beyond your self?
You whom I sent to bear my last Farewel,
Return'd to plead her stay.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: What shall I Answer?
If to have lov'd be guilt, then I have sinn'd;
But if to have repented of that Love
Can wash away my Crime, I have repented.
Yet, if I have offended past forgiveness,
Let not her suffer: she is innocent.

sp.speaker: Cleop
sp.l: Ah, what will not a Woman do who loves!
What means will she refuse, to keep that Heart
Where all her joys are plac'd! 'Twas I encourag'd,
Twas I blew up the Fire that scorch'd his Soul,
To make you jealous; and by that regain you.
But all in vain; I could not Counterfeit:
In spight of all the Damms, my Love broke o'er,
And drown'd my Heart again: Fate took th' occasion;
And thus one minutes feigning has destroy'd
My whole Life's truth.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thin Cobweb Arts of Falshood;
Se •… n, and broke through at first.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Forgive your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Forgive you Friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You have convinc'd your selves,
You plead each others Cause: What Witness have you,
That you but meant to raise my Jealousie?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Our selves, and Heav'n.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Guilt witnesses for Guilt. Hence, Love and Friendship;
You have no longer place in human Breasts,
These two have driv'n you out: avoid my sight;
I would not kill the Man whom I lov'd;
And cannot hurt the Woman; but avoid me,
I do not know how long I can be tame;
For, if I stay one minute more to think
How I am wrong'd, my Justice and Revenge
Will cry so loud within me, that my Pity
Will not be heard for either.

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: Heav'n has but
Our sorrow for our sins; and then delights
To pardon erring Man: sweet Mercy seems
Its darling Attribute, which limits Justice;
As if there were Degrees in Infinite;
And Infinite would rather want perfection
Than punish to extent.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I can forgive
A Foe; but not a Mistress, and a Friend:
Treason is there in its most horrid shape,
Where trust is greatest: and the Soul resign'd
Is stabb'd by its own Guards: I'll hear no more;
Hence from my sight for ever.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: How? for ever,
I cannot go one moment from your sight,
And must I go for ever?
My Joys, my only Joys are center'd here:
What place have I to go to? my own Kingdom?
That I have lost for you: or to the Romans?
They hate me for your sake: or must I wander
The wide World o'er, a helpless, banish'd Woman,
Banish'd for love of you; banish'd from you?
I, there's the Banishment! Oh hear me; hear me,
With strictest Justice: For I beg no favour:
And if I have offended you: then kill me,
But do not banish me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must not hear you.
I have a Fool within me takes your part;
But Honour stops my Ears.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: For pity hear me!
Wou'd you cast off a Slave who follow'd you,
Who crouch'd beneath your Spurn?—He has no pity!
See, if he gives one tear to my Departure;
One look, one kind farewel: Oh Iron heart!
Let all the Gods look down, and judge betwixt us,
If he did ever love!

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: No more: Alexas!

sp.speaker: Dolla.
sp.l: A perjur'd Villain!

sp.speaker: Anth. to Cleop.
sp.l: Your Alexas; yours.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: O 'twas his Plot: his ruinous Design
•… 'ingage you in my love by jealousie.
Hear him; confront him with me; let him speak.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I have; I have.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: And if he clear me not—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your Creature! one who hangs upon your Smiles!
Watches your Eye to say or to unsay
Whate'er you please! I am not to be mov'd.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Then must we part? Farewel, my cruel Lord,
Th'appearance is against me; and I go
Unjustifi'd, for ever from your sight.
How I have lov'd, you know; how yet I love,
My only Comfort is, I know my self:
I love you more, ev'n now you are unkind,
Than when you lov'd me most; so well, so truly,
I'll never strive against it; but die pleas'd
To think you once were mine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good Heav'n, they weep at parting.
Must I weep too? that calls 'em innocent.
I must not weep; and yet I must, to think
That I must not forgive—
Live; but live wretched, 'tis but just you shou'd,
Who made me so: Live from each others sight:
Let me not hear you meet: Set all the Earth,
And all the Seas, betwixt your sunder'd Loves:
View nothing common but the Sun and Skys:
Now, all take several ways;
And each your own sad fate with mine deplore;
That you were false, and I could trust no more.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: BE juster, Heav'n: such Virtue punish'd thus,
Will make us think that Chance rules all above,
And shuffles, with a Random hand, the Lots
Which Man is forc'd to draw.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I cou'd tear out these Eyes, that gain'd his Heart,
And had not pow'r to keep it. O the Curse
Of doting on, ev'n when I find it Dotage!
Bear witness, Gods, you heard him bid me go;
You whom he mock'd with imprecating Vows
Of promis'd Faith—I'll die, I will not bear it.
You may hold me.—
sp.stage: [She pulls out her Dagger, and they hold her.
sp.l: But I can keep my Breath; I can die inward,
And choak this Love.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Help, O Alexas help!
The Queen grows desperate, her Soul struggles in her,
With all the Agonies of Love and Rage,
And strives to sorce its Passage.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Let me go.
Art thou there, Traitor!—O
O, for a little Breath, to vent my Rage!
Give, give me way, and let me loose upon him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Yes, I deserve it, for my ill-tim'd truth.
Was it for me to prop
The Ruins of a falling Majesty?
To place my self beneath the mighty flaw,
Thus to be crush'd, and pounded into Atoms,
By its o'erwhelming weight? 'Tis too presuming
For Subjects, to preserve that wilful pow'r
Which Courts its own Destruction.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I wou'd reason
More calmly with you. Did not you o'er-rule,
And force my plain, direct, and open Love
Into these crooked paths of Jealousie?
Now, what's th' event? Octavia is remov'd;
But Cleopatra's banish'd. Thou, thou, Villain,
Has push'd my Boat, to open Sea; to prove,
At my sad Cost, if thou canst steer it back.
It cannot be; I'm lost too far; I'm ruin'd:
Hence, thou Impostor, Traitor, Monster, Devil.—
I can no more: thou, and my Griefs, have sunk
Me down so low, that I want voice to Cu •… e thee.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Suppose from Shipwrack'd Seaman near the shore,
Dropping and faint, wi •… h climbing up the Cliff,
If, from above, some Charitable hand
Pull him to safety, hazarding himself
To draw the others weight; wou'd he look back
And Curse him for his Pains? The Case is yours;
But one step more, and you have gain'd the heighth.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Sunk, never more to rise.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Octavia's gone, and Dollabella banish'd.
Believe me, Madam, Antony is yours.
His Heart was never lost; but started off
To Jealousie, Love's last retreat and covert:
Where it lies h •… d in Shades, watchful in silence,
And list'ning for the Sound that calls it back,
Some other, any Man, ('tis so advanc'd)
May perfect this unfinish'd work, which I
(Unhappy only to my self) have lest
So easie to his hand.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Look well thou do't; else—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Else, what your silence threatens—Antony
Is mounted up the Pharos; from whose Turret,
He stands surveying our Egyptian Gallies,
Engag'd with Caesar's Fleet: now Death, or Conquest.
If the first happen, Fate acquits my Promise:
If we o'ercome, the Conqueror is yours.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Have comfort, Madam: did you mark that Shout?

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Hark; they redouble it.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: 'Tis from the Port.
The loudness shows it near: good News, kind Heavens.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Osiris make it so.

sp.speaker: Serap.
sp.l: Where, where's the Queen?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: How frightfully the holy Coward stares!
As if not yet recover'd of th' Assault,
When all his Gods, and what's more dear to him,
His Offerings were at stake.

sp.speaker: Serap.
sp.l: O horror, horror!
Egypt has been; our latest hour is come:
The Queen of Nations from her ancient Seat,
Is Sunk for ever in the dark Abyss:
Time has unrowl'd her Glories to the last,
And now clos'd up the Volume.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Be more plain:
Say, whence thon com'st, (though Fate is in thy Face,
Which from thy haggard Eyes looks wildly out,
And threatens ere thou speak'st.)

sp.speaker: Serap.
sp.l: I came from Pharos;
From viewing (spare me and imagine it)
Our Lands last hope, your Navy.—

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Vanquish'd?

sp.speaker: Serap.
sp.l: No.
They fought not.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Then they fled.

sp.speaker: Serap.
sp.l: Nor that. I saw,
With Antony, your well appointed Fleet
Row out; and thrice he wav'd his hand on high,
And thrice with cheerful Crys they shouted back:
'Twas then, false Fortune, like a fawning Strumpet,
•… out to leave the Bankrupt Prodigal,
With a dissembling Smile would kiss at parting,
And flatter to the last; the well-tim'd Oars
Now dipt from every Bank, now smoothly run
To meet the Foe; and soon indeed they met,
But not as Foes. In few, we saw their Caps
On either side thrown up; the Egpptian Gallies
(Receiv'd like Friends) past through, and fell behind
The Roman rear: and now, they all come forward,
And ride within the Po •… t.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Enough, Serapion:
I've heard my doom. This needed not, you Gods:
When I lost Antony, your work was done;
'Tis but 〈◊〉 malice. Where's my Lord?
How bears he this last •… low?

sp.speaker: Serap.
sp.l: His fury cannot be express'd by words:
Thrice he Attempted headlong to have faln
Full on his Foes, and aim'd at Caesar's Galley:
With-held, he raves on you; Crys, He's betray'd
Should he now find you.—

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Shun him, 'seek your safety,
Till you can clear your Innocence.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I'll stay.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: You must not, haste you to your Monument,
While I make speed to Caesar.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Caesar! No,
I have no business with him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I can work him.
To spare your Life, and let this Madman perish.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Base fawning Wretch! wouldst thou betray him too?
Hence from my sight, I will not hear a Traytor;
'Twas thy Design brought all this ruine on us;
Serapion, thou art honest; Counsel me:
But haste, each moment's precious.

sp.speaker: Serap.
sp.l: Retire; you must not yet see Antony.
He who began this mischief,
'Tis just he tempt the Danger: let him clear you;
And, since he offer'd you his servile tongue,
To gain a poor precarious Life from Caesar,
Let him expose that fawning Eloquence,
And speak to Antony.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O Heavens! I dare not,
I meet my certain Death.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Slave, thou deserv'st it.
Not that I fear my Lord, will I avoid him;
I know him Noble: when he banish'd me,
And thought me false, he scorn'd to take my Life;
But I'll be justifi'd, and then die with him.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O pity me, and let me follow you.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: To Death, if thou stir hence. Speak, if thou canst,
Now for thy Life, which basely thou wou'dst save;
While mine I prize at this. Come, good Serapion.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O that I less cou'd fear to lose this Being,
Which, like a Snow-ball, in my Coward hand,
The more 'tis grasp'd, the faster melts away.
Poor Reason! what a wretched Aid art thou!
For still in spight of thee,
These two long Lovers, Soul and Body, dread
Their final Separation. Let me think:
What can I say, to save my self from Death?
No matter what becomes of Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: Ant. within.
sp.l: Which way? where?

sp.speaker: Ven. within.
sp.l: This leads to th' Monument.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ah me! I hear him; yet I'm unprepar'd:
My gift of lying's gone;
And this Court-Devil, which I so oft have rais'd,
Forsakes me at my need. I dare not stay;
Yet cannot far go hence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O happy Caesar! Thou hast Men to lead:
Think not 'tis thou hast conquer'd Antony;
B •… t Rome has conquer'd Egypt. I'm betray'd.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Curse on this treach'rous Train!
Their So •… l and Heav'n infect 'em all with Baseness:
And their young Souls come tainted to the World
With the first breath they draw.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Th' Original Villain sure no God created;
He was a Bastard of the Sun, by Nile.
Ap'd into Man: with all his Mother's Mud
Crusted about his Soul.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: The Nation is
One Universal Traitor; and their Queen
The very Spirit and Extract of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is there yet left
A possibility of Aid from Valour?
Is there one God unsworn to my Destruction?
The least unmortgag'd hope? for, if there be,
Methinks I cannot fall beneath the Fate
Of such a Boy as Caesar.
The World's one half is yet in Antony;
And, from each Limb of it that's hew'd away,
The Soul comes back to me.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: There yet remain
Three Legions in the Town. The last Assault
Lopt off the rest: if Death be your Design;
(As I must wish it now) these are sufficient
To make a heap about us of dead Foes,
An honest Pile for burial.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They're enough.
We'll not divide our-Stars; but side by side
Fight em •… lous: and with malicious Eyes
Survey each other's Acts: so every Death
Thou giv'st, I'll take on me, as a just Debt,
And pay thee back a Soul.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Now you shall see I love you. Not a word
Of chiding more. By my few hours of Life,
I am so pleas'd with this brave Roman Fate,
That I wou'd not be Caesar, to out-live you.
When we put off this Flesh, and mount together,
I shall be shown to all th' Etherial crowd;
Lo, this is he who dy'd with Antony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Who knows but we may pierce through all their Troops,
And reach my Veterans yet? 'Tis worth the tempting,
T' o'er-leap this Gulph of Fate,
And leave our wand'ring Destinies behind.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: See, see, that Villain;
See Cleopatra stampt upon that Face,
With all her cunning, all her Arts of Falshood!
How she looks out through those dissembling Eyes!
How he sets his Count'nance for deceit;
And promises a Lye, before he speaks!
Let me dispatch him first.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O, spare me, spare me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hold; he's not worth your killing. On thy Life,
(Which thou mayst keep, because I scorn to take it)
No Syllable to justifie thy Queen;
Save thy base tongue its Office.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Sir she's gone,
Where she shall never be molested more
By Love, or you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Fled to her Dollabella!
Die, Traitor, I revoke my Promise, die.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O hold, she is not fled.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is: my Eyes
Are open to her Falshood; my whole Life
Has been a Golden dream, of Love and Friendship.
But, now I wake, I'm like a Merchant, rows'd
From soft repose, to see his Vessel sinking,
And all his Wealth cast o'er. Ingrateful Woman!
Who follow'd me, but as the Swallow Summer,
Hatching her young ones in my kindly Beams,
Singing her flatt'ries to my morning wake;
But, now my Winter comes, she spread her wings,
And seeks the Spring of Caesar.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Think not so:
Her Fortunes have, in all things, mixt with yours.
Had she betray'd her Naval force to Rome,
How easily might she have gone to Caesar,
Secure by such a Bride!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: She sent it first,
To be more welcome after.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis too plain;
Else wou'd she have appear'd, to clear her self.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Too fatally she has; she could not bear
To be accus'd by you; but shut her self
Within her Monument: look'd down, and sigh'd;
While, from her unchang'd face, the silent tears
Dropt, as they had not leave, but stole their parting.
Some undistinguish'd words she inly murmur'd;
At last, she rais'd her Eyes; and, with such Looks
As dying Lucrece cast,—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My heart forbodes.—

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: All for the best: go on.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: She snatch'd her Ponyard,
And, ere we cou'd prevent the fatal Blow,
Plung'd it within her Breast: then turn'd to me,
Go, bear my Lord (said she) my last Farewel;
And ask him if he yet suspect my Faith.
More she was saying, but Death rush'd betwixt.
She half pronounc'd your Name with her last Breath,
And bury'd half within her.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Heav'n be prais'd.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then art thou innocent, my poor dear Love?
And art thou dead?
O those two words! their Sound shou'd be divided:
Hadst thou been false, and dy'd; or hadst thou liv'd,
And hadst been true—. But Innocence and Death!
This shows not well above. Then what am I,
The Murderer of this Truth, this Innocence!
Thoughts cannot form themselves in words so horrid
As can express my Guilt!

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Is't come to this? The Gods have been too graciou:
And thus you thank 'em for't.

sp.speaker: Ant. to Alex.
sp.l: Why stay'st thou here?

Is 〈◊〉
•… or thee to spy upon my Soul,
And see its inward mourning? Get thee hence;
Thou art not worthy to behold, what now
Becomes a Roman Emperor to perform.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: He loves her still:
His grief betrays it. Good! The joy to find
She's yet alive, compleats the Reconcilement.
I've sav'd my self, and her. But, Oh! the Romans!
Fate comes too fast upon my Wit.
Hunts me too hard, and meets me at each double:

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Wou'd she had dy'd a little sooner tho,
Before Octavia went; you might have treated:
Now 'twill look tame, and wou'd not be receiv'd.
Come, rouze your self, and lets die warm together.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will not fight: there's no more work for War.
The bus'ness of my angry hours is done.

sp.speaker: V •… n.
sp.l: Caesar is at your Gates.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why, let him enter,
〈◊〉 welcome now.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: What Lethargy has crept into your Soul?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis but a scorn of Life, and just desire
To free my self from Bondage.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Do it bravely.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will; but not by fighting. O, Ventidius!
What shou'd I fight for now? My Queen is dead.
I was but great for her; my Pow'r, my Empire,
Were but my Merchandise to buy her Love;
And conquer'd Kings, my Factors. Now she's dead,
Let Caesar take the World,—
An Empty Circle, since the Jewel's gone
Which made it worth my strife: my Being's nauseous;
For all the Bribes of Life are gone away.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Wou'd you be taken?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, I wou'd be taken;
But, as a Roman ought, dead, my Ventidius:
For I'll convey my Soul from Caesar's reach,
And lay down life my self. 'Tis time the World
Shou'd have a Lord, and know whom to obey.
We two have kept its Homage in suspence,
And bent the Globe on whose each side we trod,
Tell it was dinted inwards: Let him walk
Alone upon't; I'm weary of my part.
My Torch is out; and the World stands before me
Like a black Desart, at the approach of Night:
I'll lay me down, and stray no •… arther on.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I cou'd be griev'd,
But that I'll not out-live you: choose your Death;
For, I have seen him in such various shapes,
I care not which I take: I'm only troubled
The Life I bear, is worn to such a Rag,
'Tis scarce worth giving. I cou'd wish indeed
We threw it from us with a better Grace;
That, like two Lyons taken in the Toils,
We might at last thrust out our paws, and wound
The Hunters that inclose us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I have thought on't.
Ventidius, you must live.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I must not Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Wilt thou not live, to speak some good of me?
To stand by my fair Fame, and guard th' approaches
From the ill Tongues of Men?

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Who shall guard mine,
For living after you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Say, I command it.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: If we die well, our Deaths w •… ll speak themselves,
And need no living Witness.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou hast lov'd me,
Kill me, and take the Merit of my Death
To make thee Friends with C •… sar.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Thank your kindness.
You said I lov'd you; and, in recompence,
You bid me turn a Traitor: did I think
You wou'd have us'd me thus? that I shou'd die
With a hard thought of you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Forgive me, Roman.
Since I have heard of Cleopatra's Death,
My Reason bears no rule upon my Tongue,
But lets my thoughts break all at Random out:
I've thought better; do not deny me twice.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: By Heav'n, I will not.
Let it not be t' out-live you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Kill me first,
And then die thou: for 'tis but just thou serve
Thy Friend, before thy self.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Give me your ha •… d.
We soon shall meet again. Now farewel, Emperor.
Methinks that word's too cold to be my last:
Since Death sweeps dsstinctions, Farewel, Friend.
That's all.——
I will not make a bus'ness of a trifle:
And yet I cannot look on you, and kill you;
Pray turn your Face.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do: strike home sure.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: Home, as my Sword will reach.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O, thou mistak'st;
That wound was none of thine: give it me back:
Thou robb'st me of my Death.

sp.speaker: Ven.
sp.l: I do indeed;
But, think 'tis the first time I e'er deceiv'd you;
I •… that may plead my Pardon. And you, Gods,
Forgive me, if you will; for I die perjur'd,
Rather then kill my Friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Farewel. Ever my Leader, ev'n in Death!
My Queen and thou have got the start of me,
And I'm the lag of Honour.——Gone so soon?
Is Death no more? He us'd him carelesly,
With a familiar kindness: ere he knock'd,
Ran to the Door, and took him in his Arms,
As who shou'd say, Y' are welcome at all hours,
A Friend need give no warning. Books had spoil'd him;
•… or all the Learn'd are Cowards by profession.
'Tis not worth
My farther thought: for Death, for ought I know,
Is but to think no more Here's to be satisfi'd.
I've mist my heart. O unperforming hand!
Thou never cou'dst have err'd in a worse time.
My Fortune jades me to the last; and Death,
Like a great Man, takes state, and makes me wait
For my Admittance——.
Some perhaps from Caesar:
If he shou'd find me living, and suspect
That I plaid booty with my Life! I'll mend
My work, ere they can reach me.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Where is my Lord? where is he?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: There he lies,
And dead Ven •… idius by him.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: My sears were Prophets; I am come too late.
O that accurs'd Alexas!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Art thou living?
Or am I dead before I knew? and thou
T •… e first kind Ghost that meets me?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Help me Seat him.
Send quickly, send for help.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am answer'd.
We live both. Sit thee down, my Cleopatr •… :
I'll make the most I can of Life, to stay
A moment more with thee.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: How is it with you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tis as with a Man
Removing in a hurry; all pack'd up,
But one dear Jewel that his haste forgot;
And he, for that returns upon the spur:
So I come back, for thee.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Too long, you Heav'ns, you have been cruel to me;
Now show your mended Faith, and give me back
His fleeting Life.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It will not be, my Love.
I keep my Soul by force.
Say but thou art not false.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: 'Tis now too late
To say I'm true: I'll prove it, and die with you,
Unknown to me, Alexas feign'd my Death:
Which, when I knew, I hasted to prevent
This •… atal consequence. My Fleet betray'd
Both you and me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And Dollabella.——

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Scarce esteem'd before he lov'd; but hated now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Enough: my Life's not long enough for more.
Thou sayst thou wilt come after: I believe thee;
For I can now believe whate'er thou sayst,
That we may part more kindly.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: I will come:
Doubt not, my Life, I'll come, and quickly too:
Caesar shall triumph o'er no part of thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But grieve not, while thou stay'st
My last disastrous Times:
Think we have had a clear and glorious day;
And Heav'n did kindly to delay the Storm
Just till our close of Ev'ning. Ten years love,
And not a moment lost, but all improv'd
To th' utmost Joys: What Ages have we liv'd?
And now to die each others; and, so dying,
While hand in hand we walk in Groves below,
Whole Troops of Lovers Ghosts shall flock about u •… ,
And all the Train be ours.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Your words are like the Notes of dying Swans,
Too sweet to last. Were there so many hours
For your unkindness, and not one for Love?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, not a minute.—This one kiss—more worth
Than all I leave to Caesar.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: O, tell me so again,
And take Ten thousand kisses, for that word.
My Lord, my Lord: speak, if you yet have being;
Sigh to me, if you cannot speak; or cast
O •… e look: Do any thing that shows you live.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: He's gone too far, to hear you;
And this you see, a Lump of sensless •… lay,
The leavings of a Soul.

sp.speaker: C •… ar.
sp.l: Remember Madam,
He charg'd you not to grieve.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: And I'll obey him.
I have not lov'd a Roman not to know
What should become of his Wife; his Wife, my Charmion •…
For 'tis to that high Title I aspire,
And now I'll not die less. Let dull Octavia
Survive, to mourn him dead: my Nobler Fate
Shall knit our Spousals with a tie too strong
For Roman Laws to break.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Will you then die?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Why shou'dst thou make that Question?

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: Caesar is most merciful.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Let him be so •…
To •… hose that want his Mercy: my poor Lord
Made no such Cov'nant with him to spare me
When he was dead. Yield me to Caesar's pride?
What, to be led in Triumph through the Streets,
A Spectacle to base Plebeian Eyes;
While some dejected Friend of Antony's,
Close in a Corner, shakes his Head, and mutters
A Secret Curse on her who ruin'd him?
I'll none of that.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Whatever you resolve,
I'll follow ev'n to Death.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: I only fear'd
For you; but more shou'd fear to live without you.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Why, now 'tis as it shou'd be. Quick, my Friends,
Dispatch; ere this, the Town's in Caesar's hands:
My Lord looks down concern'd, and fears my stay,
Lest I shou'd be surpriz'd;
Keep him not waiting for his Love too long.
You, Charmion, bring my Crown and richest Jewels,
With 'em, the Wreath of Victory I made
(Vain Augury!) for him who now lies dead;
You, Iras, bring the Cure of all our Ills.

sp.speaker: Iras.
sp.l: The Aspicks, Madam?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Must I bid you twice?
'Tis sweet to die, when they wou'd force life on me,
To rush into the dark aboad of Death,
And seize him first; if he be like my Love,
He is not frightful sure.
We're now alone, in secresie and silence;
And is not this like Lovers? I may kiss
These pale, cold Lips; Octavia does not see me;
And, Oh! 'tis better far to have him thus,
Than see him in her Arms.—O welcome, welcome.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: What must be done?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Short Ceremony, Friends:
But yet it must be decent. First, this Laurel
Shall Crown my Hero's Head: he fell not basely,
Nor left his Shield behind him. Only thou
Cou'dst triumph o'er thy self; and thou alone
Wert worthy so to triumph.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: To what end
These Ensigns of your Pomp and Royalty?

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Dull, that thou art! why, 'tis to meet my Love;
As when I saw him first, on Cydnos bank,
All sparkling, like a Goddess; so adorn'd,
I'll find him once again: my second Spousals
Shall match my first, in Glory. Haste, haste, both,
And dress the Bride of Antony.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Cleop.
sp.l: Now seat me by my Lord. I claim this place;
For I must Conquer Caesar too, like him,
And win my share o'th' World. Hail, you dear Relicks
Of my Immortal Love!
O let no Impious hand remove you hence;
But rest for ever here: let Egypt give
His Death that Peace, which it deny'd his Life.
Reach me the Casket.

sp.speaker: I •… s.
